lpa_pipeline.kiv_subtypes

The KIV-2 types A, B and C are defined by three synonymous SNPs at positions 14, 41 and 86 of the first KIV-2 exon which can be seen via https://www.atherosclerosis-journal.com/cms/10.1016/j.atherosclerosis.2022.04.003/attachment/32899cc9-f3a8-4354-86a8-5ebcec782688/mmc1.pdf

The file from pipeline: https://github.com/genepi/lpa-pipeline/blob/master/files/maplocus_v3.txt suggested that Exon 421 should be bp 581-740 from his pipeline. Which can be confirmed by his next sentence “A T/C SNP 119 bp downstream of exon 1 (position 859 in [1])” Thus pos 14(A or G), 41(T or C), 86(A or T) should be pos 594, 621 and 666 in our pipeline, respectively.

Example:

krs = KIVRepeatSubtype()
krs.predict_subtype(encoding_result = encoding_result)

where encoding result is a pd.DataFrame with all value binary(or equivalent) each row should stand for an individual(id as index) and each column stand for a variant, using “pos-ref/alt” format. all of [“594-A/G”, “621-T/C”, “666-A/T”] have to be in the columns

Module Contents

Classes

KIVRepeatSubtype

class lpa_pipeline.kiv_subtypes.KIVRepeatSubtype
predict_subtype(encoding_result: pandas.DataFrame) → pandas.DataFrame

predict the KIV‐2 types A, B and C, wrappers for _predict_subtype

Parameters:

  • encoding_result – pd.DataFrame with all value binary or equivalent

  • individual (each row should stand for an) –

  • index (where id is used as) –

  • variant (and each column stand for a) –

  • format (using "pos-ref/alt") –

Returns:

have the same index as encoding_result and subtype prediction using column name “KIV-2_subtypes” as the only column

Return type:

pd.DataFrame

_predict_subtype(x: pandas.DataFrame) → str

predict the KIV‐2 types A, B and C described by:

https://doi.org/10.1016/j.atherosclerosis.2022.04.003
